I said they're invasive but eggs are a minor part of their diet. It's likely they would die in winter. They might survive in Miami but not Apopka.

I sure hope so. My wife and I spotted one in Oakland running into the protected wetlands on the south side of Lake Apopka. It was similar in size to the one in the photo. Not sure if they're getting loose at that size or smaller then growing.

I'm in Lakeland and I keep hoping for a nice cold snap to kill the bugs. A monitor should not survive a 35 degree day, I hope for a couple good freezes this year. The iguanas in Miami have managed to survive as low as 42 degrees but become paralyzed and fall from their perches.
Which I find hysterical. "Watch out for falling iguanas."
I've seen iguanas around Lake Wire in LL a 20 years ago. I was very surprised. I haven't seen one since then that was around 1999 or so. Most likely someone's pet they outgrew or escaped.

That's totally not true. Monitors are carnivores and will eat almost any type of animal that they can either overpower, or more commonly find already dead. They eat anything from fish, snakes, frogs, rats, birds and even larger animals like cats and dogs, and in the case of carrion, will tear meat from any dead animal, regardless of size.

Try again White throated and or Savannah are monitors are not carnivores try looking it up. I've had many lizards and had a herpetologist in the family. Maybe you mean Nile monitors. Wrong lizard. Savannahs and White throated are insectivores.

I just looked up Savannah Monitor. Here is what the site said: 
"In the wild, Savannah monitors are carnivores consuming small mammals, eggs, insects, carrion, small birds, small reptiles, and fish.  Although these lizards are carnivores, they have a penchant for roaches, earthworms, super worms, and other insects.  These aggressive eaters will consume nearly anything placed in front of them.  However, variety and balance are key to a healthy monitor.  Hatchlings and juveniles are primarily insectivores in the wild but in captivity can be taught to eat other foods as well such as Mazuri carnivore mixed with insectivore chow."

-Source - Chicago Exotics Animal Hospital.
